isis.stitle: POWER STEERING PUMPS LUK VT73 AND LF93 - OPERATION - FLOW CONTROL AND RELIEF VALVE

svcproc.title: FLOW CONTROL AND RELIEF VALVE
svcproc.para: Maximum flow to the operating circuit and maximum system pressure are determined by the integral flow control and relief valve subassembly (when fitted) used on the pumps in this series ( Figure 5). An orifice in the housing limits maximum flow. A pilot- operated type relief shifts to divert excess fluid delivery back to the inlet, thus limiting system pressure to a prescribed maximum.

figure.caption: Figure 5. Flow Control and Relief Valve

svcproc.para: View 3A of Figure 5 shows the condition when the total pump delivery can be passed through the orifice. This condition usually occurs only at low drive speeds.The large spring chamber is connected to the pressure port through an orifice. Pressure plus spring load in this chamber slightly exceeds pressure at the other end of the relief valve spool and the spool remains closed.

When pump delivery is more than the flow rate determined by the orifice, pressure drop builds up across the orifice and forces the spool open against the light spring. Excess fluid is throttled past the spool to the pump inlet as shown in View 3B, Figure 5.

If pressure in the system builds up to the relief valve setting (View 3C, Figure 5), the pilot poppet is forced off its seat. Fluid in the light spring chamber flows through the spool and out to the pump inlet. This flow through the small sensing orifice causes a pressure drop and prevents pressure in the light spring area from increasing beyond the relief valve setting. As pressure against the right end of the spool starts to exceed the relief valve setting, the pressure differential forces the spool to the right, against the light spring, porting the full pump flow to the pump inlet.
